dialogos.texto_completo: e "Variable names can also be shown in character names. To do that, just include the variable in square brackets in the character's name. Got it?"

dialogos.dialogo: Variable interpolation also works with other variables. Here, the answer is [answer] and the flag is [flag].
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Variable interpolation also works with other variables. Here, the answer is [answer] and the flag is [flag]."

dialogos.dialogo: Screens are the most powerful part of Ren'Py. Screens let you customize the out-of-game interface, and create new in-game interface components.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Screens are the most powerful part of Ren'Py. Screens let you customize the out-of-game interface, and create new in-game interface components."

dialogos.dialogo: What would you like to know about screens?
dialogos.texto_completo: e "What would you like to know about screens?"

dialogos.dialogo: Screens are how we create the user interface in Ren'Py. With the exception of images and transitions, everything you see comes from a screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Screens are how we create the user interface in Ren'Py. With the exception of images and transitions, everything you see comes from a screen."

dialogos.dialogo: When I'm speaking to you, I'm using the 'say' screen. It's responsible for taking dialogue and presenting it to the player.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When I'm speaking to you, I'm using the 'say' screen. It's responsible for taking dialogue and presenting it to the player."

dialogos.dialogo: And when the menu statement displays an in-game choice, the 'choice' screen is used. Got it?
dialogos.texto_completo: e "And when the menu statement displays an in-game choice, the 'choice' screen is used. Got it?"

dialogos.dialogo: Text input uses the 'input' screen, NVL mode uses the 'nvl' screen, and so on.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Text input uses the 'input' screen, NVL mode uses the 'nvl' screen, and so on."

dialogos.dialogo: More than one screen can be displayed at once. For example, the buttons at the bottom - Back, History, Skip, and so on - are all displayed by a quick_menu screen that's shown all of the time.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "More than one screen can be displayed at once. For example, the buttons at the bottom - Back, History, Skip, and so on - are all displayed by a quick_menu screen that's shown all of the time."

dialogos.dialogo: There are a lot of special screens, like 'main_menu', 'load', 'save', and 'preferences'. Rather than list them all here, I'll {a=https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/screen_special.html}send you to the documentation{/a}.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a lot of special screens, like 'main_menu', 'load', 'save', and 'preferences'. Rather than list them all here, I'll {a=https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/screen_special.html}send you to the documentation{/a}."

dialogos.dialogo: In a newly created project, all these screens live in screens.rpy. You can edit that file in order to change them.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In a newly created project, all these screens live in screens.rpy. You can edit that file in order to change them."

dialogos.dialogo: You aren't limited to these screens either. In Ren'Py, you can make your own screens, and use them for your game's interface.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "You aren't limited to these screens either. In Ren'Py, you can make your own screens, and use them for your game's interface."

dialogos.dialogo: For example, in an RPG like visual novel, a screen can display the player's statistics.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "For example, in an RPG like visual novel, a screen can display the player's statistics."

dialogos.dialogo: Which reminds me, I should probably heal you.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Which reminds me, I should probably heal you."

dialogos.dialogo: Complex screens can be the basis of whole game mechanics. A stats screen like this can be the basis of dating and life-sims.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Complex screens can be the basis of whole game mechanics. A stats screen like this can be the basis of dating and life-sims."

dialogos.dialogo: While screens might be complex, they're really just the result of a lot of simple parts working together to make something larger than all of them.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "While screens might be complex, they're really just the result of a lot of simple parts working together to make something larger than all of them."

dialogos.dialogo: Here's an example of a very simple screen. The screen statement is used to tell Ren'Py this is a screen, and its name is simple_screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Here's an example of a very simple screen. The screen statement is used to tell Ren'Py this is a screen, and its name is simple_screen." id screens_showing_1b51e9a4

dialogos.dialogo: Inside the screen statement, lines introduces displayables such as frame, vbox, text, and textbutton; or properties like action, xalign, and ypos.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Inside the screen statement, lines introduces displayables such as frame, vbox, text, and textbutton; or properties like action, xalign, and ypos."

dialogos.dialogo: I'll work from the inside out to describe the statements. But first, I'll show the screen so you can see it in action.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "I'll work from the inside out to describe the statements. But first, I'll show the screen so you can see it in action."

dialogos.dialogo: The text statement is used to display the text provided.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The text statement is used to display the text provided."

dialogos.dialogo: The textbutton statement introduces a button that can be clicked. When the button is clicked, the provided action is run.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The textbutton statement introduces a button that can be clicked. When the button is clicked, the provided action is run."

dialogos.dialogo: Both are inside a vbox, which means vertical box, statement - that places the text on top of the button.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Both are inside a vbox, which means vertical box, statement - that places the text on top of the button."

dialogos.dialogo: And that is inside a frame that provides the background and borders. The frame has an at property that takes a transform giving its position.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "And that is inside a frame that provides the background and borders. The frame has an at property that takes a transform giving its position."

dialogos.dialogo: There are a trio of statements that are used to display screens.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a trio of statements that are used to display screens."

dialogos.dialogo: The first is the show screen statement, which displays a screen and lets Ren'Py keep going.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The first is the show screen statement, which displays a screen and lets Ren'Py keep going."

dialogos.dialogo: The screen will stay shown until it is hidden.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The screen will stay shown until it is hidden."

dialogos.dialogo: Hiding a screen is done with the hide screen statement.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Hiding a screen is done with the hide screen statement."

dialogos.dialogo: The call screen statement stops Ren'Py from executing script until the screen either returns a value, or jumps the script somewhere else.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The call screen statement stops Ren'Py from executing script until the screen either returns a value, or jumps the script somewhere else."

dialogos.dialogo: Since we can't display dialogue at the same time, you'll have to click 'Okay' to continue.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Since we can't display dialogue at the same time, you'll have to click 'Okay' to continue."

dialogos.dialogo: When a call screen statement ends, the screen is automatically hidden.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When a call screen statement ends, the screen is automatically hidden."

dialogos.dialogo: Generally, you use show screen to show overlays that are up all the time, and call screen to show screens the player interacts with for a little while.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Generally, you use show screen to show overlays that are up all the time, and call screen to show screens the player interacts with for a little while."
show screen parameter_screen(_("Hello, world."), cancel=Notify(_("You can't cancel this.")))

dialogos.dialogo: Here's an example of a screen that takes three parameters. The message parameter is a message to show, while the okay and cancel actions are run when the appropriate button is chosen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Here's an example of a screen that takes three parameters. The message parameter is a message to show, while the okay and cancel actions are run when the appropriate button is chosen."

dialogos.dialogo: While the message parameter always has to be supplied, the okay and cancel parameters have default values that are used if no argument is given.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "While the message parameter always has to be supplied, the okay and cancel parameters have default values that are used if no argument is given."

dialogos.dialogo: Each parameter is a variable that is defined inside the screen. Inside the screen, these variables take priority over those used in the rest of Ren'Py.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Each parameter is a variable that is defined inside the screen. Inside the screen, these variables take priority over those used in the rest of Ren'Py."

dialogos.dialogo: When a screen is shown, arguments can be supplied for each of the parameters. Arguments can be given by position or by name.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When a screen is shown, arguments can be supplied for each of the parameters. Arguments can be given by position or by name."

dialogos.dialogo: Parameters let us change what a screen displays, simply by re-showing it with different arguments.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Parameters let us change what a screen displays, simply by re-showing it with different arguments."

dialogos.dialogo: The call screen statement can also take arguments, much like show screen does.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The call screen statement can also take arguments, much like show screen does."
call screen parameter_screen(_("Click either button to continue."))

dialogos.dialogo: There are a few properties that can be applied to a screen itself.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a few properties that can be applied to a screen itself."

dialogos.dialogo: When the modal property is true, you can't interact with things beneath the screen. You'll have to click 'Close This Screen' before you can continue.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When the modal property is true, you can't interact with things beneath the screen. You'll have to click 'Close This Screen' before you can continue."

dialogos.dialogo: When a screen has the tag property, it's treated like the tag part of an image name. Here, I'm showing a_tag_screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When a screen has the tag property, it's treated like the tag part of an image name. Here, I'm showing a_tag_screen."

dialogos.dialogo: When I show b_tag_screen, it replaces a_tag_screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When I show b_tag_screen, it replaces a_tag_screen."

dialogos.dialogo: This is useful in the game and main menus, where you want the load screen to replace the preferences screen. By default, all those screens have tag menu.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "This is useful in the game and main menus, where you want the load screen to replace the preferences screen. By default, all those screens have tag menu."

dialogos.dialogo: For some reason, tag takes a name, and not an expression. It's too late to change it.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "For some reason, tag takes a name, and not an expression. It's too late to change it."

dialogos.dialogo: The zorder property controls the order in which screens overlap each other. The larger the zorder number, the closer the screen is to the player.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The zorder property controls the order in which screens overlap each other. The larger the zorder number, the closer the screen is to the player."

dialogos.dialogo: By default, a screen has a zorder of 0. When two screens have the same zorder number, the screen that is shown second is closer to the player.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "By default, a screen has a zorder of 0. When two screens have the same zorder number, the screen that is shown second is closer to the player."

dialogos.dialogo: You're not on a small device.
dialogos.texto_completo: text _("You're not on a small device.")

dialogos.dialogo: The variant property selects a screen based on the properties of the device it's running on.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The variant property selects a screen based on the properties of the device it's running on."

dialogos.dialogo: In this example, the first screen will be used for small devices like telephones, and the other screen will be used for tablets and computers.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In this example, the first screen will be used for small devices like telephones, and the other screen will be used for tablets and computers."

dialogos.dialogo: Finally, the style_prefix property specifies a prefix that's applied to the styles in the screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Finally, the style_prefix property specifies a prefix that's applied to the styles in the screen."

dialogos.dialogo: When the 'red' prefix is given, the frame gets the 'red_frame' style, and the text gets the 'red_text' style.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When the 'red' prefix is given, the frame gets the 'red_frame' style, and the text gets the 'red_text' style."

dialogos.dialogo: This can save a lot of typing when styling screens with many displayables in them.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "This can save a lot of typing when styling screens with many displayables in them."

dialogos.dialogo: The screen language has a few statements that do things other than show displayables. If you haven't seen the section on {a=jump:warp_screen_displayables}Screen Displayables{/a} yet, you might want to check it out, then come back here.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The screen language has a few statements that do things other than show displayables. If you haven't seen the section on {a=jump:warp_screen_displayables}Screen Displayables{/a} yet, you might want to check it out, then come back here."

dialogos.dialogo: The python statement works just about the same way it does in the script. A single line of Python is introduced with a dollar sign. This line is run each time the screen updates.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The python statement works just about the same way it does in the script. A single line of Python is introduced with a dollar sign. This line is run each time the screen updates."

dialogos.dialogo: Similarly, the python statement introduces an indented block of python statements. But there is one big difference in Python in screens and Python in scripts.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Similarly, the python statement introduces an indented block of python statements. But there is one big difference in Python in screens and Python in scripts."

dialogos.dialogo: The Python you use in screens isn't allowed to have side effects. That means that it can't do things like change the value of a variable.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The Python you use in screens isn't allowed to have side effects. That means that it can't do things like change the value of a variable."

dialogos.dialogo: The reason for this is that Ren'Py will run a screen, and the Python in it, during screen prediction.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The reason for this is that Ren'Py will run a screen, and the Python in it, during screen prediction."

dialogos.dialogo: The default statement lets you set the value of a screen variable the first time the screen runs. This value can be changed with the SetScreenVariable and ToggleScreenVariable actions.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The default statement lets you set the value of a screen variable the first time the screen runs. This value can be changed with the SetScreenVariable and ToggleScreenVariable actions."

dialogos.dialogo: The default statement differs from the Python statement in that it is only run once. Python runs each time the screen updates, and hence the variable would never change value.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The default statement differs from the Python statement in that it is only run once. Python runs each time the screen updates, and hence the variable would never change value."

dialogos.dialogo: The if statement works like it does in script, running one block if the condition is true and another if the condition is false.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The if statement works like it does in script, running one block if the condition is true and another if the condition is false."

dialogos.dialogo: The for statement takes a list of values, and iterates through them, running the block inside the for loop with the variable bound to each list item.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The for statement takes a list of values, and iterates through them, running the block inside the for loop with the variable bound to each list item."
on "show" action Notify(_("The screen was just shown."))
key "a" action Notify(_("You pressed the 'a' key."))

dialogos.dialogo: The on and key statements probably only make sense at the top level of the screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The on and key statements probably only make sense at the top level of the screen."

dialogos.dialogo: The on statement makes the screen run an action when an event occurs. The 'show' event happens when the screen is first shown, and the 'hide' event happens when it is hidden.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The on statement makes the screen run an action when an event occurs. The 'show' event happens when the screen is first shown, and the 'hide' event happens when it is hidden."

dialogos.dialogo: The key event runs an event when a key is pressed.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The key event runs an event when a key is pressed."

dialogos.dialogo: The screen language use statement lets you include a screen inside another. This can be useful to prevent duplication inside screens.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The screen language use statement lets you include a screen inside another. This can be useful to prevent duplication inside screens."

dialogos.dialogo: Take for example this screen, which shows two stat entries. There's already a lot of duplication there, and if we had more stats, there would be more.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Take for example this screen, which shows two stat entries. There's already a lot of duplication there, and if we had more stats, there would be more."

dialogos.dialogo: Here, we moved the statements that show the text and bar into a second screen, and the use statement includes that screen in the first one.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Here, we moved the statements that show the text and bar into a second screen, and the use statement includes that screen in the first one."

dialogos.dialogo: The name and amount of the stat are passed in as arguments to the screen, just as is done in the call screen statement.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The name and amount of the stat are passed in as arguments to the screen, just as is done in the call screen statement."

dialogos.dialogo: By doing it this way, we control the amount of duplication, and can change the stat in one place.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "By doing it this way, we control the amount of duplication, and can change the stat in one place."

dialogos.dialogo: There's not much left to see.
dialogos.texto_completo: text _("There's not much left to see.")

dialogos.dialogo: The transclude statement goes one step further, by letting the use statement take a block of screen language statements.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The transclude statement goes one step further, by letting the use statement take a block of screen language statements."

dialogos.dialogo: When the included screen reaches the transclude statement it is replaced with the block from the use statement.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When the included screen reaches the transclude statement it is replaced with the block from the use statement."

dialogos.dialogo: The boilerplate screen is included in the first one, and the text from the first screen is transcluded into the boilerplate screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The boilerplate screen is included in the first one, and the text from the first screen is transcluded into the boilerplate screen."

dialogos.dialogo: Use and transclude are complex, but very powerful. If you think about it, 'use boilerplate' is only one step removed from writing your own Screen Language statement.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Use and transclude are complex, but very powerful. If you think about it, 'use boilerplate' is only one step removed from writing your own Screen Language statement."

dialogos.dialogo: There are quite a few screen displayables. Here, I'll tell you about some of the most important ones.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are quite a few screen displayables. Here, I'll tell you about some of the most important ones."

dialogos.dialogo: What would you like to know about?
dialogos.texto_completo: e "What would you like to know about?"

dialogos.dialogo: There are a few properties that every screen language displayable shares. Here, I'll demonstrate them for you.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a few properties that every screen language displayable shares. Here, I'll demonstrate them for you."

dialogos.dialogo: First off, every screen language displayable supports the position properties. When the container a displayable is in supports it, you can use properties like align, anchor, pos, and so so on.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "First off, every screen language displayable supports the position properties. When the container a displayable is in supports it, you can use properties like align, anchor, pos, and so so on."

dialogos.dialogo: And the world turned upside down...
dialogos.texto_completo: text _("And the world turned upside down..."):

dialogos.dialogo: The at property applies a transform to the displayable, the same way the at clause in the show statement does.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The at property applies a transform to the displayable, the same way the at clause in the show statement does."
#                 text _("This is an event.") at textform

dialogos.dialogo: The id property is mostly used with the say screen, which is used to show dialogue. Outside of the say screen, it isn't used much.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The id property is mostly used with the say screen, which is used to show dialogue. Outside of the say screen, it isn't used much."

dialogos.dialogo: It tells Ren'Py which displayables are the background window, 'who' is speaking, and 'what' is being said. This used to apply per-Character styles, and help with auto-forward mode.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "It tells Ren'Py which displayables are the background window, 'who' is speaking, and 'what' is being said. This used to apply per-Character styles, and help with auto-forward mode."

dialogos.dialogo: The style property lets you specify the style of a single displayable.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The style property lets you specify the style of a single displayable."

dialogos.dialogo: The style_prefix property sets the prefix of the style that's used for a displayable and its children.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The style_prefix property sets the prefix of the style that's used for a displayable and its children."

dialogos.dialogo: For example, when the style_prefix property is 'green', the vbox has the 'green_vbox' style, and the text in it has the 'green_text' style.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "For example, when the style_prefix property is 'green', the vbox has the 'green_vbox' style, and the text in it has the 'green_text' style."

dialogos.dialogo: There are a few more properties than these, and you can find the rest in the documentation. But these are the ones you can expect to see in your game, in the default screens.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a few more properties than these, and you can find the rest in the documentation. But these are the ones you can expect to see in your game, in the default screens."

dialogos.dialogo: Sometimes you'll have a displayable, like an image, that you want to add to a screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Sometimes you'll have a displayable, like an image, that you want to add to a screen."

dialogos.dialogo: This can be done using the add statement, which adds an image or other displayable to the screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "This can be done using the add statement, which adds an image or other displayable to the screen."

dialogos.dialogo: There are a few ways to refer to the image. If it's in the images directory or defined with the image statement, you can just put the name inside a quoted string.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a few ways to refer to the image. If it's in the images directory or defined with the image statement, you can just put the name inside a quoted string."

dialogos.dialogo: An image can also be referred to by its filename, relative to the game directory.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "An image can also be referred to by its filename, relative to the game directory." id add_displayable_8ba81c26

dialogos.dialogo: Other displayables can also be added using the add statement. Here, we add the Solid displayable, showing a solid block of color.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Other displayables can also be added using the add statement. Here, we add the Solid displayable, showing a solid block of color."

dialogos.dialogo: In addition to the displayable, the add statement can be given transform properties. These can place or otherwise transform the displayable being added.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In addition to the displayable, the add statement can be given transform properties. These can place or otherwise transform the displayable being added."

dialogos.dialogo: Of course, the add statement can also take the at property, letting you give it a more complex transform.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Of course, the add statement can also take the at property, letting you give it a more complex transform."

dialogos.dialogo: The screen language text statement adds a text displayable to the screen. It takes one argument, the text to be displayed.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The screen language text statement adds a text displayable to the screen. It takes one argument, the text to be displayed."

dialogos.dialogo: In addition to the common properties that all displayables take, text takes the text style properties. For example, size sets the size of the text.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In addition to the common properties that all displayables take, text takes the text style properties. For example, size sets the size of the text."

dialogos.dialogo: The text displayable can also interpolate values enclosed in square brackets.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The text displayable can also interpolate values enclosed in square brackets."

dialogos.dialogo: When text is displayed in a screen using the text statement, variables defined in the screen take precedence over those defined outside it.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When text is displayed in a screen using the text statement, variables defined in the screen take precedence over those defined outside it." id text_displayable_32d76ccb

dialogos.dialogo: Those variables may be parameters given to the screen, defined with the default or python statements, or set using the SetScreenVariable action.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Those variables may be parameters given to the screen, defined with the default or python statements, or set using the SetScreenVariable action."

dialogos.dialogo: There's not much more to say about text in screens, as it works the same way as all other text in Ren'Py.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There's not much more to say about text in screens, as it works the same way as all other text in Ren'Py."

dialogos.dialogo: The layout displayables take other displayables and lay them out on the screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The layout displayables take other displayables and lay them out on the screen."

dialogos.dialogo: For example, the hbox displayable takes its children and lays them out horizontally.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "For example, the hbox displayable takes its children and lays them out horizontally."

dialogos.dialogo: The vbox displayable is similar, except it takes its children and arranges them vertically.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The vbox displayable is similar, except it takes its children and arranges them vertically."

dialogos.dialogo: Both of the boxes take the box style properties, the most useful of which is spacing, the amount of space to leave between children.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Both of the boxes take the box style properties, the most useful of which is spacing, the amount of space to leave between children."

dialogos.dialogo: The grid displayable displays its children in a grid of equally-sized cells. It takes two arguments, the number of columns and the number of rows.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The grid displayable displays its children in a grid of equally-sized cells. It takes two arguments, the number of columns and the number of rows."

dialogos.dialogo: The grid has to be full, or Ren'Py will produce an error. Notice how in this example, the empty cell is filled with a null.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The grid has to be full, or Ren'Py will produce an error. Notice how in this example, the empty cell is filled with a null."

dialogos.dialogo: Like the boxes, grid uses the spacing property to specify the space between cells.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Like the boxes, grid uses the spacing property to specify the space between cells."

dialogos.dialogo: Grid also takes the transpose property, to make it fill top-to-bottom before it fills left-to-right.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Grid also takes the transpose property, to make it fill top-to-bottom before it fills left-to-right."

dialogos.dialogo: And just to demonstrate that all cells are equally-sized, here's what happens when once child is bigger than the others.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "And just to demonstrate that all cells are equally-sized, here's what happens when once child is bigger than the others."

dialogos.dialogo: The fixed displayable displays the children using Ren'Py's normal placement algorithm. This lets you place displayables anywhere in the screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The fixed displayable displays the children using Ren'Py's normal placement algorithm. This lets you place displayables anywhere in the screen."

dialogos.dialogo: By default, the layout expands to fill all the space available to it. To prevent that, we use the xsize and ysize properties to set its size in advance.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "By default, the layout expands to fill all the space available to it. To prevent that, we use the xsize and ysize properties to set its size in advance."

dialogos.dialogo: When a non-layout displayable is given two or more children, it's not necessary to create a fixed. A fixed is automatically added, and the children are added to it.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When a non-layout displayable is given two or more children, it's not necessary to create a fixed. A fixed is automatically added, and the children are added to it."

dialogos.dialogo: Finally, there's one convenience to save space. When many displayables are nested, adding a layout to each could cause crazy indent levels.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Finally, there's one convenience to save space. When many displayables are nested, adding a layout to each could cause crazy indent levels."

dialogos.dialogo: The has statement creates a layout, and then adds all further children of its parent to that layout. It's just a convenience to make screens more readable.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The has statement creates a layout, and then adds all further children of its parent to that layout. It's just a convenience to make screens more readable."

dialogos.dialogo: In the default GUI that Ren'Py creates for a game, most user interface elements expect some sort of background.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In the default GUI that Ren'Py creates for a game, most user interface elements expect some sort of background."

dialogos.dialogo: Without the background, text can be hard to read. While a frame isn't strictly required, many screens have one or more of them.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Without the background, text can be hard to read. While a frame isn't strictly required, many screens have one or more of them."

dialogos.dialogo: But when I add a background, it's much easier. That's why there are two displayables that are intended to give backgrounds to user interface elements.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "But when I add a background, it's much easier. That's why there are two displayables that are intended to give backgrounds to user interface elements."

dialogos.dialogo: The two displayables are frame and window. Frame is the one we use above, and it's designed to provide a background for arbitrary parts of the user interface.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The two displayables are frame and window. Frame is the one we use above, and it's designed to provide a background for arbitrary parts of the user interface."

dialogos.dialogo: On the other hand, the window displayable is very specific. It's used to provide the text window. If you're reading what I'm saying, you're looking at the text window right now.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "On the other hand, the window displayable is very specific. It's used to provide the text window. If you're reading what I'm saying, you're looking at the text window right now."

dialogos.dialogo: Both frames and windows can be given window style properties, allowing you to change things like the background, margins, and padding around the window.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Both frames and windows can be given window style properties, allowing you to change things like the background, margins, and padding around the window."

dialogos.dialogo: One of the most flexible displayables is the button displayable, and its textbutton and imagebutton variants.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "One of the most flexible displayables is the button displayable, and its textbutton and imagebutton variants."

dialogos.dialogo: A button is a displayable that when selected runs an action. Buttons can be selected by clicking with the mouse, by touch, or with the keyboard and controller.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A button is a displayable that when selected runs an action. Buttons can be selected by clicking with the mouse, by touch, or with the keyboard and controller."

dialogos.dialogo: Actions can do many things, like setting variables, showing screens, jumping to a label, or returning a value. There are many {a=https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/screen_actions.html}actions in the Ren'Py documentation{/a}, and you can also write your own.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Actions can do many things, like setting variables, showing screens, jumping to a label, or returning a value. There are many {a=https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/screen_actions.html}actions in the Ren'Py documentation{/a}, and you can also write your own."

dialogos.dialogo: It's also possible to run actions when a button gains and loses focus.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "It's also possible to run actions when a button gains and loses focus."

dialogos.dialogo: A button takes another displayable as a child. Since that child can be a layout, it can take as many children as you want.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A button takes another displayable as a child. Since that child can be a layout, it can take as many children as you want." id button_displayables_47af4bb9

dialogos.dialogo: In many cases, buttons will be given text. To make that easier, there's the textbutton displayable that takes the text as an argument.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In many cases, buttons will be given text. To make that easier, there's the textbutton displayable that takes the text as an argument."

dialogos.dialogo: Since the textbutton displayable manages the style of the button text for you, it's the kind of button that's used most often in the default GUI.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Since the textbutton displayable manages the style of the button text for you, it's the kind of button that's used most often in the default GUI."

dialogos.dialogo: There's also the imagebutton, which takes displayables, one for each state the button can be in, and displays them as the button.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There's also the imagebutton, which takes displayables, one for each state the button can be in, and displays them as the button."

dialogos.dialogo: An imagebutton gives you the most control over what a button looks like, but is harder to translate and won't look as good if the game window is resized.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "An imagebutton gives you the most control over what a button looks like, but is harder to translate and won't look as good if the game window is resized."

dialogos.dialogo: Buttons take Window style properties, that are used to specify the background, margins, and padding. They also take Button-specific properties, like a sound to play on hover.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Buttons take Window style properties, that are used to specify the background, margins, and padding. They also take Button-specific properties, like a sound to play on hover."

dialogos.dialogo: When used with a button, style properties can be given prefixes like idle and hover to make the property change with the button state.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When used with a button, style properties can be given prefixes like idle and hover to make the property change with the button state."

dialogos.dialogo: A text button also takes Text style properties, prefixed with text. These are applied to the text displayable it creates internally.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A text button also takes Text style properties, prefixed with text. These are applied to the text displayable it creates internally."
action Notify(_("You clicked the other button."))

dialogos.dialogo: Of course, it's prety rare we'd ever customize a button in a screen like that. Instead, we'd create custom styles and tell Ren'Py to use them.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Of course, it's prety rare we'd ever customize a button in a screen like that. Instead, we'd create custom styles and tell Ren'Py to use them."

dialogos.dialogo: The bar and vbar displayables are flexible displayables that show bars representing a value. The value can be static, animated, or adjustable by the player.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The bar and vbar displayables are flexible displayables that show bars representing a value. The value can be static, animated, or adjustable by the player."

dialogos.dialogo: The value property gives a BarValue, which is an object that determines the bar's value and range. Here, a StaticValue sets the range to 100 and the value to 66, making a bar that's two thirds full.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The value property gives a BarValue, which is an object that determines the bar's value and range. Here, a StaticValue sets the range to 100 and the value to 66, making a bar that's two thirds full."

dialogos.dialogo: A list of all the BarValues that can be used is found {a=https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/screen_actions.html#bar-values}in the Ren'Py documentation{/a}.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A list of all the BarValues that can be used is found {a=https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/screen_actions.html#bar-values}in the Ren'Py documentation{/a}."

dialogos.dialogo: In this example, we give the frame the xsize property. If we didn't do that, the bar would expand to fill all available horizontal space.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "In this example, we give the frame the xsize property. If we didn't do that, the bar would expand to fill all available horizontal space."

dialogos.dialogo: There are a few different bar styles that are defined in the default GUI. The styles are selected by the style property, with the default selected by the value.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "There are a few different bar styles that are defined in the default GUI. The styles are selected by the style property, with the default selected by the value."

dialogos.dialogo: The top style is the 'bar' style. It's used to display values that the player can't adjust, like a life or progress bar.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The top style is the 'bar' style. It's used to display values that the player can't adjust, like a life or progress bar."

dialogos.dialogo: The middle style is the 'slider' value. It's used for values the player is expected to adjust, like a volume preference.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The middle style is the 'slider' value. It's used for values the player is expected to adjust, like a volume preference." id bar_displayables_c2aa4725

dialogos.dialogo: Finally, the bottom style is the 'scrollbar' style, which is used for horizontal scrollbars. When used as a scrollbar, the thumb in the center changes size to reflect the visible area of a viewport.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Finally, the bottom style is the 'scrollbar' style, which is used for horizontal scrollbars. When used as a scrollbar, the thumb in the center changes size to reflect the visible area of a viewport."

dialogos.dialogo: The vbar displayable is similar to the bar displayable, except it uses vertical styles - 'vbar', 'vslider', and 'vscrollbar' - by default.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The vbar displayable is similar to the bar displayable, except it uses vertical styles - 'vbar', 'vslider', and 'vscrollbar' - by default."

dialogos.dialogo: Bars take the Bar style properties, which can customize the look and feel greatly. Just look at the difference between the bar, slider, and scrollbar styles.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Bars take the Bar style properties, which can customize the look and feel greatly. Just look at the difference between the bar, slider, and scrollbar styles."

dialogos.dialogo: Imagemaps use two or more images to show buttons and bars. Let me start by showing you an example of an imagemap in action.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Imagemaps use two or more images to show buttons and bars. Let me start by showing you an example of an imagemap in action."

dialogos.dialogo: Swimming seems like a lot of fun, but I didn't bring my bathing suit with me.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Swimming seems like a lot of fun, but I didn't bring my bathing suit with me."

dialogos.dialogo: I've heard that some schools have a competitive science team, but to me research is something that can't be rushed.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "I've heard that some schools have a competitive science team, but to me research is something that can't be rushed."

dialogos.dialogo: Really good background art is hard to make, which is why so many games use filtered photographs. Maybe you can change that.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Really good background art is hard to make, which is why so many games use filtered photographs. Maybe you can change that."

dialogos.dialogo: To demonstrate how imagemaps are put together, I'll show you the five images that make up a smaller imagemap.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "To demonstrate how imagemaps are put together, I'll show you the five images that make up a smaller imagemap."

dialogos.dialogo: The idle image is used for the background of the imagemap, for hotspot buttons that aren't focused or selected, and for the empty part of an unfocused bar.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The idle image is used for the background of the imagemap, for hotspot buttons that aren't focused or selected, and for the empty part of an unfocused bar."

dialogos.dialogo: The hover image is used for hotspots that are focused but not selected, and for the empty part of a focused bar.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The hover image is used for hotspots that are focused but not selected, and for the empty part of a focused bar."

dialogos.dialogo: Notice how both the bar and button are highlighted in this image. When we display them as part of a screen, only one of them will show up as focused.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Notice how both the bar and button are highlighted in this image. When we display them as part of a screen, only one of them will show up as focused."

dialogos.dialogo: Selected images like this selected_idle image are used for parts of the bar that are filled, and for selected buttons, like the current screen and a checked checkbox.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Selected images like this selected_idle image are used for parts of the bar that are filled, and for selected buttons, like the current screen and a checked checkbox."

dialogos.dialogo: Here's the selected_hover image. The button here will never be shown, since it will never be marked as selected.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Here's the selected_hover image. The button here will never be shown, since it will never be marked as selected."

dialogos.dialogo: Finally, an insensitive image can be given, which is used when a hotspot can't be interacted with.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Finally, an insensitive image can be given, which is used when a hotspot can't be interacted with."

dialogos.dialogo: Imagemaps aren't limited to just images. Any displayable can be used where an image is expected.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Imagemaps aren't limited to just images. Any displayable can be used where an image is expected."

dialogos.dialogo: Here's an imagemap built using those five images. Now that it's an imagemap, you can interact with it if you want to.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Here's an imagemap built using those five images. Now that it's an imagemap, you can interact with it if you want to."

dialogos.dialogo: To make this a little more concise, we can replace the five images with the auto property, which replaces '%%s' with 'idle', 'hover', 'selected_idle', 'selected_hover', or 'insensitive' as appropriate.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "To make this a little more concise, we can replace the five images with the auto property, which replaces '%%s' with 'idle', 'hover', 'selected_idle', 'selected_hover', or 'insensitive' as appropriate."

dialogos.dialogo: Feel free to omit the selected and insensitive images if your game doesn't need them. Ren'Py will use the idle or hover images to replace them.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Feel free to omit the selected and insensitive images if your game doesn't need them. Ren'Py will use the idle or hover images to replace them."

dialogos.dialogo: The hotspot and hotbar statements describe areas of the imagemap that should act as buttons or bars, respectively.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The hotspot and hotbar statements describe areas of the imagemap that should act as buttons or bars, respectively."

dialogos.dialogo: Both take the coordinates of the area, in (x, y, width, height) format.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Both take the coordinates of the area, in (x, y, width, height) format."

dialogos.dialogo: A hotspot takes an action that is run when the hotspot is activated. It can also take actions that are run when it's hovered and unhovered, just like a button can.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A hotspot takes an action that is run when the hotspot is activated. It can also take actions that are run when it's hovered and unhovered, just like a button can."

dialogos.dialogo: A hotbar takes a BarValue object that describes how full the bar is, and the range of values the bar should display, just like a bar and vbar does.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A hotbar takes a BarValue object that describes how full the bar is, and the range of values the bar should display, just like a bar and vbar does."

dialogos.dialogo: A useful pattern is to define a screen with an imagemap that has hotspots that jump to labels, and call that using the call screen statement.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A useful pattern is to define a screen with an imagemap that has hotspots that jump to labels, and call that using the call screen statement."

dialogos.dialogo: That's what we did in the school example I showed before. Here's the script for it. It's long, but the imagemap itself is fairly simple.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "That's what we did in the school example I showed before. Here's the script for it. It's long, but the imagemap itself is fairly simple."

dialogos.dialogo: Imagemaps have pluses and minuses. On one hand, they are easy for a designer to create, and can look very good. At the same time, they can be hard to translate, and text baked into images may be blurry when the window is scaled.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Imagemaps have pluses and minuses. On one hand, they are easy for a designer to create, and can look very good. At the same time, they can be hard to translate, and text baked into images may be blurry when the window is scaled."

dialogos.dialogo: It's up to you and your team to decide if imagemaps are right for your project.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "It's up to you and your team to decide if imagemaps are right for your project."

dialogos.dialogo: Sometimes, you'll want to display something bigger than the screen. That's what the viewport displayable is for.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Sometimes, you'll want to display something bigger than the screen. That's what the viewport displayable is for."

dialogos.dialogo: Here's an example of a simple viewport, used to display a single image that's far bigger than the screen. Since the viewport will expand to the size of the screen, we use the xysize property to make it smaller.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Here's an example of a simple viewport, used to display a single image that's far bigger than the screen. Since the viewport will expand to the size of the screen, we use the xysize property to make it smaller."

dialogos.dialogo: By default the viewport can't be moved, so we give the draggable, mousewheel, and arrowkeys properties to allow it to be moved in multiple ways.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "By default the viewport can't be moved, so we give the draggable, mousewheel, and arrowkeys properties to allow it to be moved in multiple ways."

dialogos.dialogo: When I give the viewport the edgescroll property, the viewport automatically scrolls when the mouse is near its edges. The two numbers are the size of the edges, and the speed in pixels per second.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When I give the viewport the edgescroll property, the viewport automatically scrolls when the mouse is near its edges. The two numbers are the size of the edges, and the speed in pixels per second."

dialogos.dialogo: Giving the viewport the scrollbars property surrounds it with scrollbars. The scrollbars property can take 'both', 'horizontal', and 'vertical' as values.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Giving the viewport the scrollbars property surrounds it with scrollbars. The scrollbars property can take 'both', 'horizontal', and 'vertical' as values."

dialogos.dialogo: The spacing property controls the space between the viewport and its scrollbars, in pixels.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The spacing property controls the space between the viewport and its scrollbars, in pixels."

dialogos.dialogo: The xinitial and yinitial properties set the initial amount of scrolling, as a fraction of the amount that can be scrolled.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The xinitial and yinitial properties set the initial amount of scrolling, as a fraction of the amount that can be scrolled."

dialogos.dialogo: Finally, there's the vpgrid displayable. It combines a viewport and a grid into a single displayable, except it's more efficient than either, since it doesn't have to draw every child.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Finally, there's the vpgrid displayable. It combines a viewport and a grid into a single displayable, except it's more efficient than either, since it doesn't have to draw every child."

dialogos.dialogo: It takes the cols and rows properties, which give the number of rows and columns of children. If one is omitted, Ren'Py figures it out from the other and the number of children.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "It takes the cols and rows properties, which give the number of rows and columns of children. If one is omitted, Ren'Py figures it out from the other and the number of children."

dialogos.dialogo: Ren'Py supports playing movies. There are two ways of doing this.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Ren'Py supports playing movies. There are two ways of doing this."

dialogos.dialogo: The first way allows you to show a movie as an image, along with every other image that's displayed on the screen.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The first way allows you to show a movie as an image, along with every other image that's displayed on the screen."

dialogos.dialogo: To do this, we first have to define an image to be a Movie displayable. Movie displayables take a movie to play, and can be given position properties.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "To do this, we first have to define an image to be a Movie displayable. Movie displayables take a movie to play, and can be given position properties."

dialogos.dialogo: Then, we can show the movie displayable, which starts the movie playing.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "Then, we can show the movie displayable, which starts the movie playing."

dialogos.dialogo: When we no longer want to play the movie, we can hide it.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "When we no longer want to play the movie, we can hide it."

dialogos.dialogo: The other way to show a movie is with the renpy.movie_cutscene python function. This shows the movie fullscreen, either until it ends or until the user clicks.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "The other way to show a movie is with the renpy.movie_cutscene python function. This shows the movie fullscreen, either until it ends or until the user clicks."

dialogos.dialogo: A Movie displayable can also take a mask with an alpha channel, which lets you make movie sprites. But that's more complicated, so I'll stop here for now.
dialogos.texto_completo: e "A Movie displayable can also take a mask with an alpha channel, which lets you make movie sprites. But that's more complicated, so I'll stop here for now."
